custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This collection was donated by Leland Stowe to the Edward R. Murrow Center in multiple installments, circa 1979-1984. See correspondence between Stowe and Hewson A. Ryan, Director, Edward R. Murrow Center. This collection was transferred to the Archives with the Edward R. Murrow papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection documents Stowe's work as a war correspondent during World War II and the Korean War, as well as his later career as a journalism professor. Included are photographic portraits of Stowe, 1939-1945; interviews with Lt. Col. Walter Soderholm and General Pershing; lectures and articles, 1946-1952; University of Michigan journalism lectures and teaching files, 1956-1969; manuscripts and annotated publications, 1933-1980; and one poster-sized image of CBS correspondents (including Murrow), cameramen, and soundmen during the Korean War, 1952.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Leland Stowe was born on November 10, 1899 in Southbury, Connecticut. After graduating from Wesleyan University, he joined the New York Herald Tribune in 1922. Stowe was still a reporter for the Tribune in 1929 when he covered the Paris Reparations Conference, his coverage of the conference won him the Pulitzer Prize for foreign correspondence.

In 1939 Stowe went to Europe as a correspondent for the Chicago Daily News to report on the outbreak of World War II. He went on to report on combat around the globe, including China and Burma in 1942 and the Eastern front, first for the Chicago Daily News and then for the New York Post and the American Broadcasting Company. From 1952 to 1954, Stowe was director of Radio Free Europe's news service. In 1956, Mr. Stowe became a professor at the University of Michigan, retiring in 1969. He continued to write, working as both roving editor and writer for the Reader's Digest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes photographic portraits of Stowe, 1939-1945; interviews with Lt. Col. Walter Soderholm and General Pershing; lectures and articles, 1946-1952; University of Michigan journalism lectures and teaching files, 1956-1969; Photocopy of Stowe's first edition publication "Nazi Germany Means War," December 1933; photocopy manuscripts of Stowe's "Behind the Lines: The Untold Story of Leland Stowe's Supressed Exclusive Revelations of the Burma Road and Chiang Kai-Shek Regime's Scandals and Corruption, 1942" "His Expose of the Burma Road Racketeering and Widespread Corruption in Nationalist China's Chiang Kai-Shek Government," and "How and Why Four of His Seven Dispatches - the First Ordered to Report these Dismaying Facts - Were Ordered to be Supressed by the State Department, or the White House . . . in Late December, 1941;" and compilations of records annotated by Stowe, including "Between the Crossfires from Right-wing and Left-wing Extremists: The Case History of a Liberal Correspondent and News Commentator, 1937-1955," "Copies of the FBI's Files Concerning Leland Stowe: With Analyses and Annotations by Him, August 1980."
Also included is one poster-sized image of CBS correspondents (including Murrow), cameramen, and soundmen during the Korean War, 1952.
